name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: The first item on the agenda is the debate on seven motions for resolutions on human rights violations, including religious freedoms, in Burkina Faso (2019/2980(RSP)).

name: Assita KANKO
text: Author. Mr President, my heart is bleeding because my home country of Burkina Faso, once a secular one, is groaning under the terror of Islamic radicalisation and violence by jihadist terrorists. They first sowed death and destruction in Syria and now threaten the whole of Sahel with their heinous ideology of death. By attacking churches and mosques, they have only one goal: to destroy the community. They focus on those places where people get together, pray, laugh, sing and love each other. Regional terror has global consequences. The geopolitical implications can be enormous, especially for Europe, primarily in the area of migration. But let us not forget the attacks at the heart of our Union. This is one of the reasons why the EU must continue to support the Countries of the Sahel to ensure security in the region. But sustainable development and a strong trade policy within the framework of the EU-Africa strategy are also essential. Prosperity is often a dam against terror regimes. We must not leave Burkina Faso and the Sahel behind. Otherwise, a fire is looming and the sparks will quickly spill over to Europe. Remember: Burkina was secular.

name: Ellie CHOWNS
text: author. – Mr President, no one should be subjected to violence because of their religion or any other aspect of their identity, ethnicity, sexuality, political beliefs. No one, never. Sadly in Burkina Faso such targeted violence has been increasing, with over 750 people killed this year and hundreds of thousands displaced, resulting in an unprecedented humanitarian emergency.  But Burkina Faso has a long history of religious tolerance, something to be celebrated and supported to the utmost, and I’d like to pay tribute to all of those brave people in every community who are drawing on that tradition, working to resist any attempt to provoke inter-religious conflict, because human security is not bought with weapons. Indeed, we’ve seen in Burkina Faso that the government strategy of executing suspects simply causes further radicalisation. The forces of law and order in Burkina Faso must always respect human rights if they want to create security rather than fear.  But beyond this, human security means guaranteeing people’s right to a decent livelihood and basic services. Extremism doesn’t grow in a vacuum, it grows where there is little hope. Multiple pressures, including climate change, are contributing to the erosion of livelihoods in Burkina Faso and indeed EU agricultural policy is part of the problem, with subsidised milk powder eroding the foundations of the local dairy industry.  So we must ensure that the European response to human rights abuses in Burkina Faso is coherent and rooted in a broad concept of human security and we must support all those working to resist extremism and help them to build peace through dialogue.

name: Maria ARENA
text: Author. Mr President, Burkina Faso is a secular country, which was the first country in West Africa to create the Fraternal Union of Believers, presided over and co-chaired since 1972 by Christians and Muslims. Burkina Faso therefore has a great tradition of interfaith dialogue. Unfortunately, since 2015, Burkina Faso, like all Sahel countries, has been facing serious violence against civilian populations by jihadists and armed groups, targeting all moderate religious communities, attacking the country's fundamental base of dialogue and openness, and seeking to create lawless zones in the Sahel. The root causes of poverty in this area must be addressed, causes that are the weakness of the state, but also the corruption that plagues these regions. Security must be guaranteed and we call for the G5 Sahel to continue and be strengthened in its security actions. Finally, we call for urgent humanitarian assistance to be released in this region because there are more than 1.5 million people who are now suffering from hunger in this region. It is not just by justifying the security issue that we will get there. The issue of hunger and humanitarian aid is paramount.

name: Idoia VILLANUEVA RUIZ
text: Author. – Mr President, the Sahel region is in a very serious humanitarian human rights crisis. Terrorist attacks are on the rise, while climate change is causing severe droughts and chronic famine. In Burkina Faso, four times as many civilians had been killed by December as in all of 2018. The European Union's view so far on the Sahel has had two components: the first, securization, understanding security simply as a defensive issue, security that is not improving, and, the second component, the containment of African migration that the Sahel uses as a route to reach our shores. We are no longer implementing a real security and human rights policy. Security does not depend on the soldiers we send, it depends, fundamentally, on the justice we promote. We need to change trade and economic policies, anchored in a postcolonial model; we need global debt and taxation policies; we need to change a global agri-food model that prevents farmers from living in the countryside right now; we need a gender-based approach to peace-building and security policies, and to really bet on democracy by supporting and strengthening civil society and its demands in the face of economic interests, many of them Europeans, who are sustaining this situation.

name: Jan-Christoph OETJEN
text: Author. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which The humanitarian situation in the Sahel countries is currently depressing: Burkina Faso is mentioned here, and I believe that we must see the Sahel states as a whole, together with the neighbouring states: Mali, With Niger, with the other neighbouring countries. It has already been said that Burkina Faso was once a country where religions lived peacefully together, and that is no longer the case today. Religion used to play no role, honestly, but today it matters. It is not only a question of Christians being persecuted by jihadists, but also of moderate Muslims being the target of attacks. This shows that there is a culture, a situation where people no longer trust each other, where we have major problems in interreligious dialogue. Therefore, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that we must set out to provide more support for this region. This has something to do with perspectives for people so that they do not become radicalised. But this also has something to do with the fact that we are providing military support. Mrs President has just said that security does not depend on soldiers. But security also depends on soldiers. In this respect, we Europeans need to be even more involved in this region.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: Author. - Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank you for your support. I am pleased that today's decision has succeeded in breaking the wall of indifferentness towards suffering people, including Christians, here in Parliament. As one of the initiators of today's decision, I see it as a joint success that we have made it a question of political parties to help people in need in Burkina Fasó. We've been getting it for months, reading the cries for help from the country for deepening terror. International jihadist organizations have launched a manhunt against Christians and the traditionally moderate Muslim population. They have a clear purpose. The disintegration of interfaith peace, the chaos of society and the country. My own country, Hungary, is looking for a solution on the ground again. In recent days, Azbej Tristan, undersecretary of state for Hungary Helps, has been discussing easing the refugee crisis in Burkina Faso, despite the life-threatening security situation. The Secretary of State has reported that local Christian churches are taking a lion's share of the nearly 600,000 internally-provided refugees in the shadow of the terrorist threat. A particularly valuable element of today's decision is its recognition of the self-debating work of aid organisations with religious backgrounds. The European Union is Burkina Faso's largest development donor. However, this alone is not enough to solve it.

name: Peter van DALEN
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. Mr President, in an increasing number of countries, Islamic extremists are turning deadly to subject as many people as possible to a series of excessive laws and regulations. The same is true in Burkina Faso. There, Muslims and Christians have been able to live relatively peacefully side by side for a long time until deadly attacks and persecutions began a few years ago by groups affiliated with Al Qaeda and Nusrat al-Islam. In particular, Christians and moderate Muslims are targeted. Almost every weekend a church in the northern regions of Burkina Faso is attacked. Schools are also targeted. Pastors and pastors are being driven out. Many Christians are fleeing. The need is great because of these attacks and the drought. Large flows of refugees are the result. The EU must continue to provide aid to this country and the whole region and step up it. Attacks by extremists must be strongly condemned and countered where possible.

name: Neena GILL
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, the situation in Burkina Faso has continued to deteriorate throughout this year and it is important that we look at this situation in a more holistic way rather than just focus on one group or one country. What should really concern us most is that the Sahel region has become, as we’ve already heard, a new home for Isis, which is benefiting from the insecurity of one of the poorest, least governed parts of the world. Therefore, I ask the High Representative for a strategy to be developed that addresses West Africa.  We need to support these countries, whose armed forces are under-resourced and their counter-insurgency strategies are lacking, to say the least. Their conduct of executing suspects without trial only serves to inflame the conflict and drive more people into the hands of the militants.  So my question is, what is being done by the European Union to add our voice to the UN’s calls for full investigation of abuses by the G5 Joint Forces and that we continue to address the challenges in human rights compliances by all the armies in that region.

name: María Soraya RODRÍGUEZ RAMOS
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. "Mr President, Mr. High Representative, Burkina Faso is among the ten poorest countries in the world and since 2015 has been in unprecedented violence. In the first half of 2019 there have been more than 300 terrorist attacks and armed jihadist terrorist groups have turned this area into a youth recruitment area and focused their attacks this year on schools, mosques and churches.  This situation has generated more than half a million displaced persons who also join those displaced by the situation in Mali. It means that in a country where more than four people out of five need agriculture to survive, the malnutrition threshold is below the emergency threshold. That is why this region needs the Sahel, an anti-terrorism strategy, a peace and security strategy; but Burkina Faso, today too, needs emergency food aid and development aid.

name: Mounir SATOURI
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, this resolution paints a difficult picture of Burkina Faso today. Let me remind you, however, that dialogue is and remains a pillar in Burkina Faso. Between populations, ethnicities, religions, national cohesion still exists. In reality, we are facing a political and territorial crisis here. These crises add up to the consequences of global warming. Burkina Faso is fighting to ensure that extreme poverty is not the breeding ground for jihadism. Our countries and Europe have a major responsibility and our action is misunderstood by the people. We are coming out again from a G5 that is a failure. An addition of weaknesses will never make a strength, and it is urgent for France, Europe and the rest of the international community to rethink the Sahelian strategy. It is time to take a sincere and frank assessment and learn from our long history of failure. It is with the people that stability must be rebuilt.

name: Alessandro PANZA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, for some time now there has been a real hunt for Christians in Burkina Faso and beyond.  There are more than 12 jihadist groups linked to Isis and Al Qaeda in the country, which since 2015 have been responsible for more than 650 deaths and more than half a million displaced persons, also due to the inadequacy of the Armed Forces.  In 2019 alone, which has not yet ended, 74 Christians have already been killed, of which 3 are priests. During the last attack on the first Sunday of Advent, a group of Islamic terrorists stormed a church during a mass, killing 14 men, women, children and operating the priest on the altar from which he was officeing. Burkina Faso has now become a land of martyrdom for minorities. It is time for this Parliament to commit itself to considering not only this State for its riches, but above all for its fragilities, acting in practice. I would like to end this speech by wishing everyone, and in particular those Christians who risk their lives for their faith, a peaceful Christmas and reminding this House that hiding our Judaeo-Christian roots so as not to shock the sensibilities of others only weakens those communities of Christians who risk their lives to profess their faith. Merry Christmas to everyone.

name: Bert-Jan RUISSEN
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Mr President, radical Islamic violence has transformed Burkina Faso from a once peaceful country, characterised by religious tolerance, into a hotbed of extremism. The country's Christian minority is badly affected. In 2019 alone, more than 60 Christians have been killed in targeted attacks. Churches are closed and Christians are being driven out of their villages. I'm very worried. All the more so because the violence is not confined to Burkina Faso but also increases throughout the Sahel region. International action is therefore urgently needed. I call on the European Union to take the situation of Christians in the region into account in its common security policy and also in the new EU-Africa strategy. This is to prevent elimination of the Christian presence in Burkina Faso and in the region.

name: Isabel BENJUMEA BENJUMEA
text: – Mr President, unfortunately, the case we condemn today, the attack on a Christian church in Burkina Faso is not an isolated case. We are living in recent years a true religious persecution against Christians; religious persecution that is taking place not only in Burkina Faso, but also in Nigeria, in Afghanistan, in Somalia, in Sri Lanka and in so many other countries. It is a religious persecution, let us be clear, of Islamist terrorists against Christians. They are being murdered in cold blood just because they profess a faith. The data speaks for themselves and is chilling. According to a report by the Organization Open Doors, in 2018 more than 4,000 Christians were killed by the mere fact of professing their faith, 3,125 were arrested and more than 1,800 churches were attacked. Ladies and gentlemen, let us not deceive ourselves, especially those who so strongly defend multiculturalism. These attacks are attacks on everything that the West and the European Union represent, they are attacks on our values, on our way of life; in short, attacks on our freedom. We can't remain impassive.

name: Jackie JONES
text: – Mr President, other colleagues have spoken about the situation in Burkina Faso and that it is known for its religious and cultural tolerance. I want to congratulate those colleagues and the country for that. These attacks are absolutely terrible, but we have to think about it in the context of a much broader agenda. First of all, I want to give my condolences for everyone who has died, to their families and friends and for the suffering that they have endured because of attacks. It doesn’t matter where in the world. I’m not just talking about Burkina Faso. As far as I am concerned, suffering violence is a virus that reaches dark and deep into our countries, into our democracies and into our very hearts, and that’s something that we have to try and stop at all cost. So what do I mean by that? I think no country is immune from attacks and we have to think very carefully about what we do in the Africa—EU strategy that is coming up and how we address the situation. My view is that we need to show solidarity, cooperation and friendship, and of course funding, but positive rather than negative steps to make sure that we are one world and one human race, not divided.

name: Nathalie LOISEAU
text: Mr President, the litany of terrorist attacks in Burkina Faso is overwhelming, and it has been going on for several years. It targets both military and civilians; it hits restaurants, markets, churches, schools. The reality is that the situation is only getting worse. It is time for the European Union to better target its aid to build proper republican security forces. We must continue to invest in long-term training schools for the police, for the gendarmerie, for the army. Member States must also overcome their reluctance and we must be more present on the ground to accompany those we train. But the Burkinabe authorities must also tell us how they want to reclaim their territory and with what support from us. Support notably military, but also for the internal security forces, for justice, for customs. Time is running out; we need a European strategy for the Sahel, built with the Sahelians. We have all the tools to act and we are acting more than anyone, but we need to coordinate better to meet this considerable security challenge in the Sahel, a challenge that is primarily African, but also our own.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: Mr President, half a million displaced people, nearly 2,000 schools closed and sometimes targeted simply for teaching in French. And in the watermark, a growing persecution of Christians in the embarrassed and guilty silence of the West - evidenced by the new attack earlier this month on a Protestant church in the east of the country, with fourteen victims. Thus the Burkinabe state is gradually crumbling, a guarantee of stability in West Africa and a bulwark against Islamist terrorism. Thus also ends the burning of the Sahel from a conflict initially limited to northern Mali. We would find it hard to be surprised sincerely when we know that only, or almost 4,500, French soldiers are sweeping away the vast Sahelian state, while the UN mission in Mali is reduced to impotence. I hear from all my colleagues, Ms. Loiseau, everyone agrees. However, the debates within the hushed walls of the European Parliament will not change anything until the Union takes stock of the stakes in this region whose future is crucial, both for Christianity and for Europe. Take note of it on this day, this Christmas.

name: Tomasz Piotr PORĘBA
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I am very pleased with this debate today, because this is such a good time to condemn, firstly, the recent attacks in Burkina Faso, to express solidarity with the government, with ordinary people. But I also think that this is such a good time for us all to reflect here on what we can do as the European Union to restore stability in this country and calm the situation in the whole region.  These attacks, which have taken place in recent weeks, particularly against the Christian community, attacks by radical Islamist groups linked to ISIS have led to many tragedies. In recent attacks on churches, dozens of people, even young children, were killed when machine guns were fired. This is the time to start real action to restore stability in this country. There is a large role for the High Representative of the European Union when it comes to foreign affairs. We need a strategy, we certainly need to unlock humanitarian aid, we need real action, and I call for that action and I ask for it.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by No further than the first december there was an armed attack on a church in Burkina Faso. It killed 14 people and injured many others. In 2019 alone, 40 Christians lost their lives at the hands of jihadists in Burkina Faso. Aggression has increased in recent years. It has forced hundreds of thousands of citizens to flee their homes. Hundreds of people lost their lives. Basic human rights are violated, schools are closed and religious freedom is regularly violated.  Today, we call on the Government of Burkina Faso to take more intensive action to protect religious minorities, including Christians, and to counter radicalisation in this country. At the same time, we must remember that Burkina Faso is facing many problems. It is one of the ten poorest countries in the world, plagued by internal conflicts. I am aware that the government may not be able to meet this challenge on its own. The European Union should therefore work with the Government of Burkina Faso and the Group of Five for the Sahel and support security efforts. I also believe that the European Union must continue its humanitarian assistance to Burkina Faso.

name: Joachim KUHS
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the We too will vote in favour of the resolution. We should be aware, however, that the political measures do not eliminate the real problem of human rights violations and the persecution of Christians. The number of persecuted Christians alone has now risen to more than 200 million, and only at the weekend at least 33 people were murdered by Islamists in Congo. So what is our response to this deadly hatred? For Christians who want to follow Jesus' example, there can only be one answer: Love your enemies. Jesus himself told His disciples, "If they have persecuted me, they will persecute you too." Well, can love really be the answer? Yes, because God Himself loved the world so much that He gave his own Son. And that's the real message of Christmas. Only it can help us in the current precarious situation. That is why I wish all of us a merry, blessed and merciful Christmas.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Mr President, I listened with interest to the whole debate. I agree with the authors of this resolution and it is up to the Representative of the European Commission to say how our new policy, the European Commission's policy towards this unfortunate country, will take shape.  The description of the increasing violence in this country, which has so far been religiously tolerant, is very well described in the motion for a resolution itself and has also been described by the previous speaker in this debate. The facts are very sad and need not be repeated. Let us talk about how we can help this country, what assistance we can provide to the government there, which, unfortunately, is failing to combat violent attacks by Islamists against the civilian population. The worst thing about the whole thing is that this violence has an upward trend, that there have been dozens of attacks against the civilian population in the last six months, and that the government of this country is not quite able to cope. So let us talk about how the European Commission, and therefore the European Union, can help the government there to protect the civilian population.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: – Mr President, yes, as one of our colleagues said, we are on the verge of the winter holidays, at Christmas, and behold, we are once again witnessing a situation such as that of Burkina Faso, with violence, with people killed. I agree with the resolution and believe that, not only that, for seven years, we have been helping the European Union, with funds, this community, I think it is important that in the EU-Africa Strategy, the new High Representative, together with the UN, bring concrete measures to enhance safety and security. Because nothing is more valuable than people's lives and here we have two situations.  On the one hand, the serious situation, the poverty there, the deaths of people due to poverty, but also violence and cases of bombings and terrorism. I think we have a lot of work to do here with the UN because yes, there is a strategy of the UN, and of ours, of the European Union, but we must look at measures and whether the effects of our measures lead to an improvement in the situation. We are human and I believe that through faith and love we can solve much more than through words.

name: Mick WALLACE
text: – Mr President, Burkina Faso and Sahel are incredibly challenging areas now, and if we were wondering what the European community can do in a positive way, we’ve got to take a different approach to this region. We are not tackling the causes of the instability, climate change, illicit tax flows through our corrupt financial institutions in the global north, exploitation by our corrupt extractive industries and western support for corrupt administrations. We don’t have clean hands. We’re robbing the place blind. We steal their minerals. These countries are unstable because they’re so poor, and we are helping to keep them poor. We have to stop robbing them. And all our money and expansion into the military in the area has failed – it’s got worse since we put troops in there. We need to help the governments to recover. We need to stop robbing these people and help them to have normal countries.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Mr President, I would also like to call on the High Representative to take action, to support this country, Burkina Faso, which has de facto collapsed from a relatively functioning state under the influence of years of jihadist violence. We must, of course, condemn – and I fully join in the condemnation of my colleagues – the incredible violence that is being permeated against Christians and is not avoiding children, or, of course, even moderate Muslims. We must support the democratic structures of this country, support their armed forces, that is, I think, our primary task, at the same time, to support a country that is in a multi-year drought, from which hundreds of thousands of refugees are actually leaving.  I am satisfied with the draft resolution, I will support it, but I would also like to call on the European Union, the High Representative, to focus our attention and strategy on the whole of the Western Sahel. It's an area that needs our help, and if he doesn't get it, it's possible he'll go back towards the jihadists.

name: Josep BORRELL FONTELLES
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy . – Mr President, honourable Members, all of you are right. In recent months, we have seen a continued and dramatic deterioration of the security situation in Burkina Faso. I was reading more figures than what has been mentioned. 700 victims in this year, 500 just since the summer; multiple attacks of various kinds against armed forced, security forces, civilian villages, schools, health. It makes almost 700 000 people displaced. This situation puts the level of food crisis very high. These people need assistance and basic social services. More than one million people are in need of emergency food assistance. This summer the country recorded more than 2 000 schools closed. It means more than 300 000 children are out of school. Almost 10 000 teachers affected; several of them have been killed during this year. The situation is weakening the central authorities while the next presidential election is already approaching and considering that the authorities have started to be criticised by the opponents for their crisis management. Burkina Faso as a strong partner for us, and despite the fact that some difficulties appeared recently concerning the crisis assessment, I think we have to be more present and more engaged in this area. In fact, Christians represent 25% of the population. It is often seen as an example of peaceful religious coexistence, but it is clear that the terrorist groups want to undermine this inter-faith coexistence as part of a broader strategy of fomenting inter-ethnic and religious conflict and generate a continued displacement of the population. They attack communities that they consider as enemies, but also those Muslims that are considered by Jihadist groups as too moderate, as shown by the attack on a mosque in October. This situation doesn’t call for a retreat but for urgent and strong action. As signatories of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, Burkina Faso and the international community share the obligation to save life, to protect the dignity of the population and to defend effective freedom of belief. That’s why we are following the situation and acting on the areas where security is under strain. We are indeed strongly committed to reinforce our support to the fight against radicalisation. Setting up a humanitarian and human rights law compliance framework require resources. We are funding the G5 Sahel force with 10 million and peaceful co-existence between communities with almost the same amount of money, and supporting the civil society in the field of democracy with another 7 million. This is an example, some illustrations of what do we do in this specific purpose. Preserving social cohesion and religious coexistence is key for the stabilisation of the country. I would like to reassure you that the EU will continue supporting Burkina Faso in facing this critical challenge, because the situation in Burkina and in general in Sahel affects very much the security and peaceful prospects, also for us Europeans. Thank you for this debate and for bringing the attention of the European Parliament to this sad situation. (Applause)

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place after the end of the discussions. Written declarations (Rule 171 of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Thierry MARIANI
text: In writing. The clashes at work in the former Upper Volta must generate our deep concern. The country is a direct victim of Islamist radicalization in the Sahelian strip and suffers from regular intrusions by jihadist officials, especially the Peul ethnic group, or from secular clashes between opposing ethnic groups. Contrary to what many are now suggesting, the situation in the whole region would worsen without the courageous investment of the French armies. I would like to add that the current situation proves the lack of national cooperation between Member States of the European Union in the region, leaving the French army to isolation. I will of course support this text despite two dubious provisions: the first is the refusal to name the enemy, masking under religious clashes, the perpetuation of Islamist raids on the animist and Christian populations, the second is the remark made on the use of force by the Burkinabe army which faces challenges far more dangerous than the comfortable moral lessons of our resolutions. I stand with the persecuted Christians of Burkina Faso.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on six motions for resolutions on Afghanistan, namely allegations of sexual abuse of boys in Logar Province (2019/2981(RSP)).

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: Author. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. I am pleased that, above political divisions, we are speaking out on this important issue, a painful issue, because the sexual exploitation of young people is always something that is awful. And In my opinion, the voice of the European Parliament in the context of the very many cases in Afghanistan in Logar province must sound very strong.  I would like us to put pressure on the authorities of this country, which receives enormous humanitarian and economic assistance from us, to do everything to ensure that such situations do not take place in the future, in order to limit the opportunities for sexual exploitation of young people, because it means a stigma for them for life. We should act in solidarity on this matter. I am pleased that this is a common position of the representatives of the various political groups, and I am pleased that Commissioner Borrell will also be able to take a position on this issue as Commissioner with the most experience in the European Commission and former President of the European Parliament.

name: Erik MARQUARDT
text: Author. Mr President, I would like to thank the I always have such a problem that when we talk about Afghanistan in the European Parliament, we are actually only talking about the dark side. I know that Afghanistan has its downsides. But it is also the case that one should perhaps talk about the happy sides from time to time: about happy families, about the great food, about beautiful sunsets in Kabul. I know that is not the issue today. But I find it a bit sad that this country – which has two sides – is often not represented by either side. I was in Afghanistan as a photojournalist in 2016 and 2017, and of course the dark side was not hidden there. But I also met many great people there: many people who also fought for human rights and democracy. It has to be said that it is people like Mohammad Musa Mahmudi and Also Ehsanullah Hamidi who work tirelessly there for human rights, to whom we deserve thanks. It is all the worse that these human rights defenders may be sometimes less protected than the criminals who commit crimes against children there. The two human rights defenders wanted to protect children from sexual abuse and they were arrested on the way to a meeting with the EU ambassador. It is important that we therefore put this issue on the agenda here, that we acknowledge in the resolution that the authorities there now want to take steps to better protect human rights defenders, including to investigate these allegations independently. But it is important that we stick there, that we look closely there, that these crimes do not go unpunished, that the safety of human rights defenders is protected, and that we also say that anyone who wants to receive financial aid from us must stand up for human rights defenders, and that must not go unpunished when children are abused. We raise various points in the resolution, and I am very grateful that it has been possible to find such a broadly united resolution here in Parliament in order to send out a strong signal. Thank you also to colleagues for that.

name: Kati PIRI
text: author. – Mr President, this is the brutal picture that shocked us all. Local Afghani elites buy or kidnap boys from poor families. They dress them up as women, make them dance and then abuse them sexually. This is ‘bacha bazi’, but we should not mince words: this is sex slavery and it is absolutely reprehensible. Last month’s report showed just how bad the situation is. In Logar, at least 136 boys, and probably thousands more, were systematically abused, by their teachers and local authorities – by the people to whom they look up the most – and it did not end there. Several boys were killed, of which five by their families because of the shame they supposedly brought to their communities.  The Afghan authorities must therefore immediately suspend all alleged perpetrators of ‘bacha bazi’. They need to conduct an independent investigation into all allegations and hold perpetrators to account. This abhorrent practice must be rooted out once and for all.

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: Author. – Mr President, we fully endorse and support this resolution. Cases of child sexual abuse are one of the most atrocious realities and, in the case of Afghanistan, a war that should have been avoided and has not brought overwhelming consequences not only for the country, but also for the region. Unfortunately, the case of the 136 young people is just one example, as between 2015 and 2018 more than 14,000 children were abused in Afghanistan. This photograph is, however, wider and, therefore, we wanted to appeal to colleagues to support the amendments we have tabled to the resolution. As I said, we fully support this resolution, but in the context of a broader photograph, we cannot ignore that the report by the Us Special Inspector General said and demonstrated that foreign troops, under the purview of the United States, had been explicitly advised not to intervene in these cases of violations and abuses against minors. We also know today that American troops were aware of the abuses of the Afghan security forces. We also know today, through Human Rights Whatch, that there have been violations committed by paramilitary groups supported by the United States. Now that everyone knows and we know that, we would like to include in this resolution the need for an independent investigation so that impunity does not remain. We would also like to include in this resolution a call on member states to stop deporting Afghan minors who, when they return to the country, face are risks of torture and violation of human rights, as this resolution demonstrates.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: author. – Mr President, crimes against children are the worst possible form of crime. It destroys and takes away childhood from Afghan kids. Moreover, it affects their life and their future. And their future is the future of Afghanistan, which we work hard to create. Over the past days, we observed President Ghani’s commitment to investigate dreadful events in the schools of Logar province. We express our appreciation to this reaction and look forward to the concrete results. All perpetrators must be brought to justice and schools return to being a safe place for kids. One of the main tasks of our common efforts in reconstructing Afghanistan is about a secure future for the country’s young generation. We will continue our support for eradicating the practice of bacha bazi and promoting and protecting the rights of children in Afghanistan.

name: Željana ZOVKO
text: author. – Mr President, a couple of weeks ago we celebrated the 30th anniversary of the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child, and with this debate we can conclude that there is still a lot of work to be done to protect children around the world.  I would like to express my grave concerns regarding the allegation of sexual abuse in several schools in Logar Province. The protection of the lives and welfare of children should be central to every society, especially during times of armed conflict. In addition, I also strongly regret the arbitrary detention of the human rights defenders who reported the alleged exploitation and violation.  The Afghan authorities should ensure in all circumstances that human rights defenders are able to carry out their human rights work. Following up on these cases, I call upon the Attorney General’s Office to launch an independent and impartial investigation into the allegation of abuse, as well as the arbitrary detention of the human rights defenders.  The EU delegation and EU Member States with diplomatic missions in Kabul should continue following developments in these cases and fully implement the EU guidelines for the promotion and protection of the rights of children in armed conflicts. Furthermore, it is paramount for the European Union to increase the scrutiny and monitoring of EU financial assistance to Afghanistan. This way, we can ensure that the budget provided will support the conducive environment for the protection of children and human rights defenders.

name: Isabel SANTOS
text: on behalf of the S&D Group– Mr President, the situation discussed here of the demeanable bacha bazi custom in Logar province, Afghanistan, deserves only the most hearty repudiation. Under the cover of a so-called tradition, the eyes have been closed for too long to a blatant violation of children's rights and the most basic rules of human rights. The steps, finally taken, by the Afghan government to eradicate this custom are insufficient and reports continue to arrive of abused children and human rights defenders attacked and arbitrarily detained.  It is time to demand that all those who fight for children's rights be released and protected and to ensure the full eradication of this practice of abuse. An end to impunity and access to justice and non-extradition should be put to an end when they take refuge in other countries. We know that mentalities take a long time to change and therefore the mobilisation of Afghan society, activists, authorities and religious leaders is required. All are necessary in combating this scourge and legislative change is required, but also intervention through education in order to protect future generations.

name: Christine ANDERSON
text: On behalf of the ID Group, I would like to make a i-see of the Mr President, I would like to thank the The abuse of children in Afghanistan is appalling, the sexual abuse of every child is appalling. Unfortunately, this form of abuse is not uncommon in Islamic countries and ultimately nothing more than an expression of the culture prevailing there. The problem here, however, is that the European Parliament once again presumes to use its index finger to denounce the grievances of other countries. We hear again Sunday speeches and empty speech bubbles of expressions of concern. Then you can feel really good again and prove your moral superiority. But they do not change the reality of these children's lives. The mere naming of the highly problematic treatment of sexuality in Islam is already an indication of racism in this country. However, if the causal cause of a problem cannot even be identified, please do not pretend that you are concerned about the fate of these children. Your publicly celebrated moral superiority, which you carry like a pop dance, is nothing more than the halo of the hypocrites.

name: Clare DALY
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, I very much welcome the resolution from the point of view of reopening the debate on the appalling practices of bacha bazi, the systemic child abuse and slavery which has long been well known in parts of Afghanistan. And isn’t the saddest thing about this discussion the fact that it isn’t a revelation, it isn’t new? We’ve all known about this for a very long time. In fact, we know that even attempts to have the situation exposed and dealt with have been interfered with. American soldiers even, who tried to stop the process, were themselves disciplined for that, while such behaviour was engaged upon in military compounds where the US was present. So for me, this exposes the nonsense that we’re constantly exposed to: that the US intervention in Afghanistan was all about bringing human rights, women’s rights, education, when the knowledge of this practice took place under their eyes and they did nothing. This makes them complicit in that practice. And of course the cases should be investigated. Of course the victims must be supported and protected. But, you know, I do think we need to draw the conclusions from that. It’s a sad irony, I find, that we are condemning – appropriately so – the physical rape and enslavement of children when the country itself has been raped and pillaged by foreign intervention and its population enslaved. Afghanistan was recently ranked as the most violent country in the world, yet we send hundreds of young people back there every year. Parliament deems it too unsafe for us to visit, but we’re quite happy to send children back there every year. Shame on us. But more than that, we should be supporting their right to live in dignity and respect in their own country, free from interference. So I support the initiatives to bring peace to that country. But we should start by supporting the human rights defenders and civil rights defenders who are active in that state, and not the official echelons of power.

name: Robert BIEDROŃ
text: – Mr President, imagine a young boy, about 13 years old. He goes to school to get an education that every child deserves. Imagine that the teacher, whom the boy trusts, lures the boy into a dark room and rapes him. The boy is very brave and speaks out about his story, but when he goes to a police station, he is raped again. The boy’s family is so ashamed that they threw him out of their house. But at least, they did not kill him.  This is not an isolated incident. It is a reality for hundreds of confirmed cases in the Afghani province of Logar, where teachers and local authority officials have been implicated in the sexual abuse ring. And now, imagine that we would not do anything about it.

name: Evin INCIR
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr This debate and this resolution is about the absolute worst imaginable – it is bottomless. That is precisely why I think it is important that we have this debate and the resolution and that we take this to the highest possible level.  Sexual abuse, rape, sexual exploitation, slave trafficking and murder of children, by young people. It's sick. The widespread and ongoing abuse of boys in Logar Province in Afghanistan is a disgrace, and I would like to express my full support and solidarity with the victims. We must come to an agreement with the obligation of confidentiality and stigma surrounding this phenomenon, and the abominable so-called game of boys must end.  Those responsible must be held accountable at all stages, the justice system must work, the victims, that is, the children, must be given the support and help to which they need and are entitled. Children must be allowed to be children and grow up in safety and freedom. No man is the property of another person. The abuse must stop.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Mr President, the situation in Logar is really crazy. Unfortunately, we can describe the tragedy of the young people in Logar, express solidarity, but unfortunately we will not be able to resolve this. However, it is up to us, and it is also a question for the High Representative, what pressures, even economic pressures, we can put on the Afghan Government to at least try to deal seriously with this problem. So far, there are some promises from Afghanistan's constitutional officials, but that is not enough. We cannot accept this in this way, we need our foreign policy towards Afghanistan to clearly contain this issue, to want Afghanistan, for criminal law, which already regulates the issue of violence against children in Afghanistan, to be enforced in real terms and, in addition to this criminal line, for Afghanistan to launch a state awareness campaign to draw attention to and warn against this crazy phenomenon.  These are ways, at least indirectly, that we can help the victims of this insane violence to dwindling in the future. But without our pressure and the pressure of the global public, I fear, the situation in Afghanistan will not improve.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the recent report of the UN Secretariat shows that more than 12 000 children have been killed or maimed, that rape and that aggression against children in Afghanistan exists and, unfortunately, the measures that have been taken, even by changing the Penal Code, through a new 2019 law on the protection of children's rights, have failed, failed to protect children.  I think it is important that we vote on this resolution, but I would ask colleagues to vote on Amendment 1 in which, in particular, we accuse foreign troops in Afghanistan, under the control, under us leadership, of not intervening in child abuse cases, and I want to point out that child abuse we also have in the Member States. We have juveniles assaulted; recently, in my country, a Dutch citizen assaulted two little girls. Sure, he killed himself after he was discovered, but we have to be careful with our children, the future, the generations that will be in the world and in Europe.

name: Klára DOBREV
text: I warmly welcome you and the 500 million European citizens you represent through you.

name: Mick WALLACE
text: – Madam President, the notion of children being sexually abused has to be one of the most horrific things that we can imagine. We come from Ireland, where the sexual abuse of a lot of young people by some members of the Catholic Church has left an incredible trail of destruction. The fact is that, back in Ireland, it was known. People knew it was happening, but people were pressured into silence. It’s not credible in Afghanistan that the powers that be, the government of the day, didn’t know. The EU does want to help to restructure Afghanistan after the destruction by the Americans and others, and the Russians before them. But, if we are going to play a positive role, we have got to be very straight with the authorities there and let them know that the likes of this cannot be acceptable because, if we too stay silent, things will be slower to change. You have a positive role to play in Afghanistan and you should use your influence and potential to actually drive this home and shout loud that this is too much and too bad.

name: Josep BORRELL FONTELLES
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, for sure, there are, in our developed and affluent societies, cases of child abuse, and we could also discuss about the war in Afghanistan, and why we Western people have been there for almost 20 years. What were the causes? The consequences? We can talk about all that, we know. But today, what brings us here, in this specific case, is the part of the iceberg which is out of the water, because the data about child abuses in Afghanistan are, unhappily, much, much, much, much bigger than one could compare with our societies. The data we have shows very clearly that the Logar case is the part that you see from the iceberg. Between 2015 and 2018, the United Nation’s Task Force verified 40 000 grave violations against children throughout the country. 40 000! Many of them were of serious concern. This represents 80% of the civilian casualties. 80% of the civilian casualties are children, and not withstanding monitoring and verification constraints, the recruitment and use of 274 children and the perpetration of sexual violence against many others, the abduction of 2013, 800 attacks on schools and hospitals – well, I will not continue. It’s clear that it’s not exactly the same problem as here. In Afghanistan, in 2017 they wanted to revise the penal code, which entered into force in 2018, explicitly criminalising the so-called bacha bazi. But it’s very difficult to change the habits, the influence of powerful people. Impunity is very widespread, and victims face stigma and exclusion from society. We have to do new fighting, because this Child Protection Act had to be approved by a presidential decree, and later the lower house of the parliament refused it, arguing that they did not have a quorum to approve one article. And in December 2019, yesterday, there were still discussing it. The Law on Protection of Child Rights was rejected four times by the parliament in the last four years. It shows how strong the resistance is to change laws, and mainly habits, in a society which, unhappily, presents such kind of behaviour that we have to fight and we have to help to fight. We have to help to fight, trying to improve the rights of children in Afghanistan. We are doing as much as we can and we will continue doing so, knowing that, at the end, to change a society is much more difficult – a longer-standing endeavour than just publishing a law in a paper. We have organised recently a public debate entitled ‘Children of Afghanistan – They Deserve a Better future’ that drew wide interest from officials and the general public. In addition, our annual rights dialogue between the European Union and the Afghan Government systematically includes a chapter on the specific situation of children, where such matters as children in armed conflict, child marriage and violence against children are addressed. For sure, there are also cases of abuses inside the armed forces, and the EU addresses this matter in a systematic manner, paying attention to the minors recruited by the army and security forces and the behaviour of soldiers and policemen towards the civilian population. We have a police advisory project which includes a gender segment, which is also meant to benefit the young people. As you can see, this is a great problem. We are trying to help the Afghan authorities and society to fight against it, and I think it’s very important that the European Parliament echoes these events in order to fight against them.

name: Klára DOBREV
text: The debate is over. The vote will take place at the end of the debates.

name: Klára DOBREV
text: The next item is a debate on six motions for resolutions on the Russian Law on 'Foreign Agents' (2019/2982(RSP)).

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: author. – Madam President,  the Soviet Union was particularly oppressive and cruel towards independent journalists, many of them perishing. Unfortunately, in Putin’s Russian Federation we see that some steps taken by the state unfortunately resemble the old past. We still remember a fantastic person like Anna Politkovskaya, and very brave journalists willing to give independent, reliable information to Russian society. Unfortunately the ‘foreign agent’ act in its recent shape signed by Vladimir Putin on 2 December is a further step to intimidate individual and independent bloggers and journalists. We call in our resolution to repeal this law.

name: Viola VON CRAMON-TAUBADEL
text: Author. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has And again, Putin wants to gain even more control over his society with this law on foreign agents. The space for independent organisations, media and even freedom of thought is getting smaller and smaller. Step by step, the Kremlin deprives Russian society of all freedom. But it is not just about Russia. To silence NGOs and critics and to abolish media pluralism is Russia's most successful export article. Putin as a model for authoritarian rulers. They do not always put their opponents in prison, but they have recognized that administrative hurdles or the mere threat of sanctions lead to self-censorship. They have developed subtler and more sophisticated methods to exert pressure, complicate daily work, and then silence critics once and for all. Intimidation of NGOs is a common practice in our neighbourhood. Defamation campaigns against civil rights activists are commonplace not only outside the EU, but also in Romania, the Czech Republic or Malta. Putin's model student is Viktor Orban. In Hungary, NGOs are already obliged to register and designate foreign-funded organisations as if they receive money from abroad. We must now put a stop to these developments as quickly as possible.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Developer. – Dear Chairman, I thank my colleagues for their excellent cooperation and constructive negotiations. We have a good common text, focused on the problematic law on so-called foreign agents. Parliament's messages on this case are clear. The law was passed back in 2012, but new amendments were added last month. They extend the scope of the law to all those who publish content or share foreign media content while also receiving funds coming from outside Russia. Whether or not they are Russian citizens. Space for free work and independent media funding is further limited. We strongly condemn this law because it restricts the freedom of speech and action of civil society and the media - the fundamental freedoms of the Russian constitution. That's why we're asking for his withdrawal. Russia is a signatory to the European Convention on Human Rights and the Universal Declaration of Human Rights. We expect him to promote the values of which he is a signatory. In addition, I believe that the future relations and cooperation of the European Union with Russia should be part of a comprehensive strategy, based primarily on respect for international law.

name: Antony HOOK
text: author. – Madam President, there’s nothing more integral to democracy than free speech, and nothing more important to Europe’s security than democracy in Europe and around Europe. Our largest neighbour has taken another step that causes concern. Russia will require journalists, bloggers and others who share news to label themselves ‘foreign agents’ on pain of criminal punishment. The term is clearly pejorative and intended to make people say, ‘don’t believe me’, and will be used against those who criticise the government. This law must go. We wish for friendship, not hostility, with Russia, but we see in Russia a regime that stifles criticism and without the frequent change of who is in power that characterises democracy. We have learned that states that suppress free speech become a danger to their own people and to their neighbours. We wish sincerely to cut back the jungle of mutual suspicion. On behalf of the Renew Group, I say please let us have more free speech, not less.

name: Michael GAHLER
text: Author. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her It is regrettable that we need to talk again about tightening up the legal situation in Russia. Not only NGOs that receive financial support from abroad will be covered by this law in the future, but also individuals and bloggers who have to pin this dubious title of a foreign agent. Anyone who reports on human rights violations, environmental crimes, corruption is denounced as a foreign agent. I think the Russian citizens deserve better. Those who speak these unwelcome truths are not a foreign agent, but perceive the true interests of the citizens in the face of a small political and economic caste at the top, which is trying to propagate strength and nationalism to the outside world, but which, like no dynasty before in Russian history, enriches itself behind a potemkin state facade behind which everything is possible. Since the Russian state is trying to patronise its citizens, such as subjects during the Tsarist period or as in the Soviet Union, we should express our solidarity with the Russian citizens in such a way that we demand the immediate abolition of this law.

name: Andrius KUBILIUS
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, first of all, we need to answer a very simple question: what does this Russian ‘foreign agent’ law mean? It means that authorities in Russia are afraid of their people. That is why I would like to make an appeal. Mr Putin, don’t be afraid of ordinary Russian people. When authorities are becoming afraid of their people, they are starting to fight their people. That is when basic human rights are drastically becoming violated. That is where we need to use all our power, not only the power of the EU itself but also of the Council of Europe, where Russia again got all its rights back. We need to use the Council of Europe, we need to use the Venice Commission, we need to use our governments, which are part of the Council of Europe, really to urge all of them to defend the human rights of ordinary Russian people against the authorities, which are afraid of those people.

name: Raphaël GLUCKSMANN
text: on behalf of the group S and D. Madam President, the Committee for the Prevention of Torture: Foreign Agents! The Group Maximum, which defends LGBTI rights: agent from abroad! The NGO of Human Rights Defenders Memorial: Foreign Agent! Bellona's Greens: Agents from abroad! And now, individuals too, bloggers, journalists, intellectuals, ordinary citizens: all agents from abroad! This is the model of society that Vladimir Putin proposes. And this model, make no mistake, inspires all authoritarian movements within the European Union itself. So it's not just a diplomatic issue, it's also the confrontation of two worldviews. It is time that we, ladies and gentlemen, are as consistent in our defence of democracy as Vladimir Putin is consistent in his repeated attacks on democracy in Russia and within the European Union itself.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Madam President, for a long time, the Russian Government has been deliberately shrinking the independent media space, with few credible resources and sources remaining. Now it is targeting individuals, particularly independent journalists, political opposition and activists who might have different ideas and vision for Russia than those provided by the Kremlin. We imposed sanctions – rightly so – against Russia in reaction to its aggression in eastern Ukraine and Crimea. That was five years ago and no signs of improvement have been observed. On the contrary, Russia is becoming even more authoritarian domestically. The ‘foreign agent’ law only proves that Russia is not advancing but regressing when it comes to respect for fundamental liberties. This law affects not only Russian citizens but is also a direct attack on us, Europeans. The part that is ‘foreign’ in this law, and presumably damaging to Russian society, is us. In addition to civil society activists, our diplomats are also being stigmatised in Russia. We should not be late and should do our job on time and approve the Global Magnitsky Act without delay.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, this was a very good week for freedom of expression in the European Union, and in this Parliament on Monday the decision was taken to establish the Daphne Prize to honour investigative journalism. On Tuesday the Whistleblower Act took force in the EU, and on Wednesday we honoured freedom of expression by giving the Sakharov Prize to a famous dissident,  defender of Uyghurs Ilham Tohti, in the name of the most famous academic and dissident, Andrei Sakharov from Russia. But the contrast to what is happening in Russia could not be more sharp, and we have to be aware that the recent decision by the Russian regime to extend the law on foreign agents to individuals will seriously damage the work of independent journalists in Russia. I’m particularly wanting to mention the excellent news service of Radio Free Europe, Radio Liberty, who have hundreds of correspondents throughout the Russian Federation, and their work will now be very much more difficult. (Applause)

name: Thierry MARIANI
text: on behalf of the ID Group. - Madam President, I hope you are aware that this resolution almost condemns the United States at the same time. May I remind you that in 1938, the FARA Act, which in many respects resembles what is being passed in Russia today, already condemned foreign agents in the United States. To say the least, Russia faces a number of international adversities that sometimes defy common sense. Personally, I am appalled to see in the resolution a clear, reaffirmed will to maintain all sanctions against Russia, sanctions that are so harmful to our economy and will achieve nothing. So in Parliament, you see Russian agents everywhere. Brexit: the Russians; Trump: the Russians; yellow vests: the Russians; strikes on French trains: certainly also the Russians. In retaliation, we ban territories, we freeze assets, we condemn. In fact, until 1981, France, too, had a law that limited the possibility of forming associations for foreigners. The Council of Europe has just returned to Russia. I think it is this path that we need to follow, that of re-establishing a dialogue. We are going the other way; we're going to a dead end.

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The tightening of the rules on so-called foreign agents is another manifestation of the Kremlin's attempts to isolate Russian society from the outside world and information. This is a reaction of the Putin regime, unfortunately supported by some European countries with billions of euros (see Nord Stream 2), to the growing dissatisfaction of the Russian public with the policies of the authorities and to the growing number of local protests on socio-economic and political backgrounds. The weakening legitimacy of power against the background of economic stagnation and social problems of the population is to be compensated by the rhetoric of the besieged fortress. But there is also the other side of the matter. It is also a fact that some organisations, foundations, news agencies have excessive ambitions to democratise Russia and forget that it is the Russians themselves who have to decide in which direction their country should develop.

name: Nikolaj VILLUMSEN
text: gue/NGL Group. Madam President! Freedom of expression, the right to organise, freedom of assembly, are the cornerstones of the European Convention on Human Rights, signed by not only the EU countries but also Russia. We see in these years that fundamental democratic rights, which we otherwise took for granted, have come under pressure. Authoritarian regimes are actively working to destroy civil society. We see it within the European Union in Hungary under Orbán, we see it in Israel under Netanyahu, and we see it not least in Russia under Putin. Let us send a very clear signal today. We do not accept that fundamental human rights are being violated. We do not accept attacks on civil society. We do not accept that the Russian Government is running away from its obligation to guarantee Russian citizens freedom of expression, assembly and freedom of association.

name: Miroslav RADAČOVSKÝ
text: – Madam President, colleagues, if the European Union wants to exist as it exists and wants to play the judge of the world and the protector, the world defender of rights and freedoms from Antarctica to the Arctic, then above all it must be objective so that it does not lose face. This motion for a resolution on Russian, Russian law here is, in fact, frankly, a biased junkie. A biased junkie who doesn't come out of basic facts. So you are all talking about russia's opposition being threatened. However, I took the effort, took the effort and went through all the russian parliament votes from 2012, 2017 and 2019. 60% of the Russian Duma voted against these laws, first, second and last, and opposition Russian parties did not vote against it, so it is a decision of 250 million Russian citizens. It's a matter for Russia. It is a response to American restrictions, and therefore objectively, objectively, let us consider the matter, let us not be Russophobia, and let us also think that the world is no longer on one foot, the world is already on at least two or three legs, and the future of Europe and the future of all other countries depend on cooperation, bridge building, economic cooperation and not interference in the internal affairs of other countries.

name: David LEGA
text: – Madam President, at the core of Christian democracy is civil society, and to me, as a Christian Democrat, a free, diverse and strong civil society is a precondition for a democratic state. To others like Vladimir Putin, the mere existence of some sort of civil society is nothing but a threat to everlasting authoritarian rule. And Putin ticks quite a few anti-civil society boxes. I mean systematic efforts to intimidate the media: check. Rigging elections: check. And the ‘foreign agent’ law: check. In fact, this law is just another poorly-disguised attempt to thwart a political opposition that in Putin’s view should not exist. But it does, and it must – not least in Russia. And I do understand that it must be hard for former KGB agent Putin to grasp that there isn’t a potential spy hiding around each new corner. But until he does, Russia’s brave civil society members will have my unconditional Christian Democratic support.

name: Attila ARA-KOVÁCS
text: - Dear Fellow Members, Yesterday, standing up in this chamber and to applause, we expressed our solidarity with the Uighur spiritual leader detained by the Chinese authorities. Such a stand is credibility if, in all other similar cases, we also express our solidarity. And now there is this new Russian law, which absolutely wants to destroy, in effect, partly free thinking and partly free spirit in Russia. I will not comment on this analysis, as many people have done today, but I would like to point out that this system, the Putin regime, not only wants to build this method at home, these methods, but also export it, just as its legal predecessor, the Soviet Union, did. I regret that my own country is the first victim of this export. That's where these Putin principles, the principles of this Putin practice, fell to the ground. Unfortunately, Hungarian civil society is now in a paralyzed state, but at the same time they want to destroy the institutions that were allies of it, such as the Central European University. I would like to ask you one question. Do you know what kind of money they're going to use to fund this? From the money you give, the voters behind you. Please think about that when you press the button today.

name: Anna Júlia DONÁTH
text: – The Russian agent law must be dealt with not only because they want to silence civilians in Russia and people who want change in Russia. We must also not remain silent on the law because the means of exercising power of the Russian state, which operates as a mafia, do not stop at the Russian border, as many have already pointed out. Anti-Western disinformation is already threatening the European Union from within. Originally created against hostile states, the law is now applied to NGOs and opposition politicians in Hungary as well as in Hungary. Hungary is now Vladimir Putin's European laboratory. Here, try out how Russian solutions work in an EU Member State. For example, he is installing his spy bank in Hungary, which he wants to sell under the pseudonym International Investment Bank, and that is why Russian propaganda and the Russian news agency that makes the propaganda are infiltrating from the Hungarian public broadcaster. The European Union must do its u uts to ensure the independent functioning of NGOs and not to allow its Member States to punish and sanction legitimate rights NGOs.

name: Catherine ROWETT
text: – Madam President, yesterday this House awarded the Sakharov Prize to Ilham Tohti and welcomed two distinguished runners-up for that prize. Today, we register concern about Russia’s new ‘foreign agent’ law, which threatens journalists and NGOs. These neatly illustrate two complementary halves of a commitment to defending those who fight for freedom of thought in countries not fortunate enough to belong to this alliance of free nations. I have been honoured to play a small part in this work, at a time when freedom of thought and expression grows more precious the more intensely it is threatened. Yesterday, I also noted the unanimous absence of the Brexit plc members from the Sakharov ceremony. Colleagues will also be aware that Boris Johnson has found new ways to delay releasing the report on Russian interference in UK elections. I say no more. (Applause)

name: Hermann TERTSCH
text: – Madam President, the Kremlin's new measures of 2 December further restrict the freedoms of Russian citizens and all independent organizations. The laws against "foreign agents" of 2012 and 2015 already allowed any foreign organization or Russian organization to pursue foreign relations whose activities did not please power. With the new enlargements already, in reality, no one can have contacts abroad in Russia that cannot be used administratively or criminally against them. That is, repression in this field is already very coupled with that in force in the Soviet Union, in the communist dictatorship before 1985, when perestroika and Gorbachev arrived. This undemocratic involution, which also violates all Russia's commitments in the international field and its treaties, is tragic. That is why we call on President Putin not to condemn Russia any more to this delay than isolation imposes on it.

name: Claire FOX
text: – Madam President, it’s right to condemn Russia’s law dubbing independent bloggers and journalists as foreign agents. It’s a scary and dangerous threat to media freedom and whips up xenophobia in Russia. However, I’ve listened to so many debates in this Chamber that also cheaply blames foreign interference for everything, and there’s a danger of the pot calling the kettle black. If the EU wants the moral authority to criticise Russia, then it better clean up your own house first. How many times in this Chamber have MEPs, Commissioners and motions labelled people who don’t conform to the EU’s agenda as foreign agents of Putin or insinuate that it was Russian bots that controlled the voting habits of the public, for example in the UK’s referendum. And what’s your answer? Always censorship and bans. And all those fashionable accusations of foreign collusion can amount to whipping up anti-foreign xenophobia in our own nation states. It also strips our own voters of their agency, as though they can’t make their own mind up unless it was the Russians what did it. It prevents self-reflection on the reasons for popular discontent, instead lazily blaming foreign subversion. We should be relentless in criticising Putin’s iron grip over the Russian people and these attacks on democracy and freedom. But sadly, the EU itself shows too little regard for press freedom and popular democracy, instead scapegoating your own failures on foreigners. Beware, look to your own house.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, recent amendments to Russia’s law on foreign agents is an extremely concerning blow to civil society and freedom of the press in Russia. The Russian Parliament is continuing to create a hostile environment for journalists with excessive use of fines against the media and civil society. NGOs and journalists face troubling levels of repression as a result of efforts to encourage their self—censorship, deny their right to freedom of expression and stigmatise journalists and activists. The role of NGOs and media is vital to any democratic society, and this role is being diminished by the authorities in the context of an already shrinking space for civic engagement in Russia. This legislation is a fearmongering tool, seeking to silence human rights defenders and journalists. I would like to call on the Russian authorities to bring their legislation in line with European and international human rights standards immediately.

name: Pierfrancesco MAJORINO
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, freedom of the press and the presence of free information are essential elements for democracy and the rule of law, but Vladimir Putin pretends not to know and it will be enough, through the new law, to receive funding from abroad, to disseminate media material of unseathed organisations to be branded as foreign agents, thus ending up on a list of registered suspects monitored. , which previously concerned NGOs and several foreign newspapers and today even blogs. It is clear that we are faced with the obsessive need to control the media and restrict any room for dissent. And that is right to condemn him from here, as we are doing, but putin's friends who sit among us should think about this and think about what is a project of society that we cannot tolerate because it conflicts with our values and our democracy.

name: Phil BENNION
text: – Madam President, this revision to the law will allow the Russian Government to name independent journalists and bloggers who receive funding from any foreign source as foreign agents: a Soviet—era term for political opponents. Targeted individuals will have to label their work and register with the authorities or face fines or even imprisonment of up to two years. Such a law can be used as a tool to silence critics of the Government, further undermining a free and independent media and damaging freedom of expression. I call on the Russian Government to reverse its decision, bring its legislation into line with its obligations to international human rights law, and end its continued efforts to restrict civil-society groups and independent journalism. It is regrettable that we see this approach from Russia even alongside its re—admittance to the Council of Europe.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: – Dear President, Commissioner, colleagues, the greatest threat to the Kremlin is democracy. Now it is a turn for non-governmental organisations and the still-sparse, sparse, independent media, which is often the only source of reliable information. The aim is to shut up and put society ahead of those who do not let hope go, fight for human rights, protect the environment in Russia, and try to defend the fundamental values of democracy. The law on "foreign agents" shows that the Kremlin is afraid. Putin and the propaganda machine he controls do not work as they would like. As a result, the existence of the regime is at stake. It is becoming increasingly difficult to work on two fronts, both domestically and externally, interfering in elections and referendums in other countries. Therefore, in defending the rights of ordinary Russian people, we are defending democracy and the opportunity to survive first.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Madam President, I still remember very well what the word foreign agent meant in the former socialist Czechoslovakia and throughout the Central and Eastern European bloc, which was under the Soviet dictatorship. It was simply a term for dissidents, for those who fought for human rights, for freedom and democracy in countries such as Czechoslovakia, Poland, Hungary and other countries. Today, therefore, the Russian Ministry of Justice wants to persecution unwanted organizations and individuals, such as journalists, with this designation. The Czech organization People in Need also made the list of these organizations. This organization is the largest non-profit organization in the Czech Republic and Central Europe, which helps in the fields of human rights, development aid and education in more than thirty countries around the world. In Russia, People in Need supported independent journalists, civil society, and provided assistance to political dissidents. It is therefore completely unacceptable for a respected independent organisation from a Member State of the European Union to be regarded as an undesirable foreign agent in the Russian Federation. I therefore fully agree with the proposal to repeal this law in Russia.

name: Ramona STRUGARIU
text: – Madam President, Radio Free Europe, which has played a decisive role in the revolutions in Eastern Europe and which receives European funding on certain projects, is blacklisted by Putin, along with other media structures receiving funding from the West. The Foreign Agents Act was adopted in 2012 and required all externally funded NGOs to be entered in a register. This law has been deeply criticised by the European Parliament.  Last month, Putin passed a law extending the application to individuals, specifically journalists or political opposition leaders, which defies us. Freedom of the press is non-negotiable. As I said in July, Russia must urgently repeal laws that blatantly violate freedom of expression and contravene international standards.
