There can be no normalization of the relationship with Russia as long as human rights do not exist for Putin. The European Union's Christmas gift to Putin should be Magnitsky legislation.

name: Eugen TOMAC
text: – Madam President, for whom he had doubts that Putin is a dictator, he has the answer in this law. To who is this law dedicated to and why it was passed now? The answer is simple: those who promote, in the Russian Federation, the same set of values on which our Union is built. Who does Putin fear in the Russian Federation when he talks about democracy, freedom of expression, fundamental rights?  What is happening now must worry us and it is a wake-up call for us, for The Europeans, because the teachers targeted, the journalists targeted, the opinion leaders of the Russian Federation who do not think that Putin poses a threat to his State. Mr High Representative, we ask you to take action to defend the millions of Russian citizens who do not think like Putin and look with hope at the European Union.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: – Madam President, High Representative Borrell, the resolution which the European Parliament is voting on today on the Russian 'foreign agents' Law gives up two priorities. The first, freedom of expression and access to free information: Daphne Caruana, the Sakharov Prize. But the second, Russia and its interference in cyberspace, in Russia and also in Europe. Russia, our border, our giant neighbor. The European Union is a space of peace. The Council of Europe is also pressured until Russia's entry, from which there have been war actions by Russia against Ukraine, Russia against Georgia and between Armenia and Azerbaijan over the borders inherited from the defunc Soviet Union. We have reason to be concerned about Russia's interference in cyberspace and, therefore, this Resolution does the right thing, sending a resounding message of respect to bloggers, journalists and all those who serve a free process of public opinion formation in a country that is all controlled by Putin's regime.

name: Clare DALY
text: – Madam President, in 2017, when the panic about Russian interference was at its height, the US Government forced Russia Today and Sputnik to register as foreign agents under the Foreign Agents Registration Act. The most predictable outcome of this is, obviously, that Russia would reciprocate. This is one of the most basic principles of international relations. Every action has an equal and opposite reaction, and here we have Russia doing exactly that. And sadly, it is likely to be enforced arbitrarily. It’s a tragedy for independent journalists and citizen reporters in Russia. We only need to look at what the US have done with its ‘foreign agent’ law to see where this could lead to: Russian Maria Butina, prosecuted as a scapegoat, imprisoned as a Russian spy just for being Russian. This isn’t about Russian values being different than ours; in actual fact the Russians are copying what they’ve seen others in the West doing. And the sooner we stop this Russian scaremongering, seeing Russian agents everywhere, the better our societies will be. We need to engage in dialogue to move forward.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Madam President, this law clearly shows that the Russian regime is becoming increasingly authoritarian. We in the Czech Republic know about this because, unfortunately, a significant part of the Czech political representation headed by President Zeman supports the Putin regime. It must be said that we must protest unequivocally against this, and I am very glad that this resolution holds the line of the previous European Parliament, when we realise how undemocratic the Russian regime is and condemn its fight against human rights in Russia itself, its foreign annexation, as well as its efforts to meddling in national political situations in other countries and to influence, for example, the conduct of electoral campaigns. Russia must be our partner, but our partner is not the Putin regime. This, High Representative, must be the clear voice of the European Commission. I beg you very much, hold the line held by the previous European Commission, let us not succumb to the Russian propaganda of the Putin regime and let us be consistent in this.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: – Madam President, it has already been said here: the former USSR was over-and-for-want and cruel. Those who lived in the eastern states and felt the boots of the USSR on our lives we understand perhaps more than other colleagues. That is why I condemn the new law that Mr Putin recently gave, and I agree and vote on this resolution.  The restriction of freedom of the press does not help us either, we will never know the truth because there are also people there, and there are citizens who may want freedom, perhaps who want to move freely and bear the consequences of this law. That is why I will definitely vote for the law and we must be careful. It is our neighbour, the European Union, but we must lay down the conditions for respect ing democratic rules. That's the only way we can be good partners.

name: Silvia MODIG
text: – Mr President, as a Finn, I have lived next door to Russia my whole life. Thanks to that neighbourlyness, both friendship and cooperation between our civil society have always crossed the line. Now many of our friends are in a very difficult situation thanks to this law. Many organisations are no longer able to function. It is particularly difficult for human rights organisations and organisations that defend the rights of minorities, because it is most difficult for them to obtain funding from within Russia.  Now that the law has been extended, the situation has only worsened. The state of civil society is shrinking even further. And when free social debate is not allowed, the opposition is also silenced and a dictatorship is approached. Investigative journalism and critical media have already been muted. An incredible number of journalists have been murdered in Russia, Anna Politkovskaya as their sad symbol. I support this resolution and hope that we will continue to work to repeal this law and support Russian civil society.

name: Josep BORRELL FONTELLES
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, the European Union has a long-standing and clear position on Russia’s ‘foreign agent’ law, and the newest amendment to this law, signed by President Putin on 2 December, widens the scope of the ‘foreign agent media’ law to include individuals. Many of you have expressed your strong concern about that – and, I think, rightly, because this has the potential to affect independent journalists and bloggers and is another step towards restricting media freedom and freedom of expression in Russia. Since 2012, when the ‘foreign agent’ law was first introduced in Russia, enabling non-government organisations to be branded as foreign agents, about 150 NGOs had this label imposed on them. They have been subject to fines, inspections and stigmatisation. The impact has been to restrict fundamental freedom in Russia, consume the scarce resources of NGOs, and inhibit independent civil society in the country. In 2017, foreign agent legislation expanded, so that any media organisation receiving foreign funding, either directly or indirectly, could be labelled as a foreign agent. It has again reduced the space for free and independent media, as well as independent voices. ‘Foreign agent’ legislation goes against Russia’s human rights obligations and commitments. The EU has repeatedly condemned this legislation, most recently in a statement by the External Action Service – the spokesperson on 23 November: the extension of the law to include private individuals is yet another move to curb freedom of expression. We will continue to call on the Russian authorities to respect their international obligations on freedom of association and freedom of speech. It is essential that Russian citizens are able to exercise freedom of association, including the right to join and participate in non-governmental organisations which promote the protection of human rights and fundamental freedoms. The European Union will continue to support Russian human rights activists and civil society as we do worldwide, because this is a fundamental principle of the European Union. Our support is important, be it public statements, attending trials, supporting meetings with them. We will keep monitoring developments in Russia, calling the authorities to account when they do not respect fundamental rights enshrined in their Constitution. We will insist on the need to respect the decisions of the European Court of Human Rights and, in general, the Council of Europe conventions. That’s democracy, the rule of law and respect for human rights. (Applause)

name: Klára DOBREV
text: The debate is over. The vote will take place at the end of the debates.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: Ladies and gentlemen, today the Court of Justice of the European Union has delivered a judgment in Case C-502/19 Junqueras Vies. It is a very important judgment which directly affects the composition of this institution. We were not wasting time or making you wait for the sake of making you wait.  The Court ruled that the assumption of parliamentary office results from the vote of the electors.  The Court held that a person whose election to the European Parliament was officially proclaimed by the competent authority of the Member State in which that election took place has since acquired the status of Member of Parliament and enjoys the protection of parliamentary immunity within the meaning of Article 9 of the Protocol on the Privileges and Immunities of the European Union as from the date of the official proclamation of the results. Consequently, the position of Member of Parliament must be regarded as having been acquired by the fact alone and by the time of that proclamation. The Court also held that immunity means that the protective custody measure to which the elected Member has been subjected must be waived in order to enable the Member to go to the European Parliament and to complete the necessary formalities. Having said that, if the competent national authority considers that such a measure should be maintained after the person in question has assumed the status of Member of the European Parliament, it must request the European Parliament to waive that immunity as soon as possible, in accordance with Article 9 of that Protocol. I appeal to the competent Spanish authorities to comply with the wording of the judgment and I have ined Parliament's services to assess as soon as possible the application of the effects of the judgment on the composition of our Parliament. I would like to inform you that I will not accept points of order on this matter.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: Colleagues, after this very clear statement by the President, there is no need for further points of order or the like on the matter. I would like to welcome the Delegation of the Ukrainian Parliamentarians who participated in the Tenth meeting of the EU-Ukraine Parliamentary Association Committee yesterday and today. (Applause) This was an important meeting, being the first one held since the start of the new legislative period, both for our European Parliament and for the Verkhovna Rada of Ukraine, and therefore a good moment to look with ambition and vision at what we strive to achieve together. So, dear Ukrainian friends, the multi-faceted and very intense cooperation between our parliaments is the symbol of our commitment towards the European path chosen by Ukraine and the concretisation of our support for your country. Let me thank you for coming this week to Parliament and wish you all the very best for your work as parliamentarians at the forefront of the strengthening and deepening of your democracy. (Applause)

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: The next item is the vote. (For the results and other details of the vote: See Minutes)

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: That concludes the vote.

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: – Madam President. I had the privilege of watching a lot of the Romanian revolution in Bucharest. I was 18 years old. It was my gap year. I saw most of it through the windows of a pub called Hanul lui Manuc, because it was the only place in that city where you could get beer. It was a pub that brewed its own beer. The only things you could buy in Bucharest at that time were Italian vermouth and plum jam. It is an extraordinary thing to see the strides made by Romania since then. But it’s worth remembering that the revolution, not only in Romania but in the other Soviet satellites, was primarily about the end of foreign occupation and the restoration of national sovereignty. Yes, of course, it was about democracy, the rule of law and personal freedom, but the peoples of those countries understood that those things are meaningless unless you have mechanisms to hold your rulers to account, and that is why, as Charles de Gaulle observed many years ago, national sovereignty and democracy are the same thing.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: – Madam President, I, like my colleague Hannan, watched this revolution on tv. It was happening only a few kilometers from my home in Sofia and for the first time we saw the events happening on the streets of Bucharest, the Timisoara and other Romanian cities. Then Romania was closed, as was Bulgaria, and was under a communist dictatorship. A dictatorship that tried to destroy the memory of our peoples, a dictatorship that tried to destroy our national self-consciousness, to invent some other person – a citizen of the Soviet bloc, a Soviet citizen.  Fortunately this did not happen, fortunately this dictatorship collapsed. The collapse of the dictatorship in Romania, the events we observed on TV, the fighting on the gutters of Bucharest, also inspired many Bulgarians for the change that succeeded in overthrowing the communist dictatorship in Bulgaria and enabled our peoples to take their fate back into their hands.  Congratulations to all who participated in these events and hot congratulations to the fraternal Romanian people!

name: Jan ZAHRADIL
text: – Madam President, it is very good that we have commemorated the 30th anniversary of the fall of the communist regime in Romania. It was the last Soviet satellite, the last part of the former communist empire where communist power fell. Unfortunately, as is rightly stated in this resolution, it was also the most violent and bloodiest episode of the entire fall of the communist regime in Central and Eastern Europe. In my original homeland, in the former Czechoslovakia, we were lucky enough that the Velvet Revolution took place in our country, that not a single life was lost, and that the transfer of power and the fall of the communist regime took place in relative peace. We, of course, watched in shock on television screens what was taking place in Romania, including the execution of former dictator Ceaușescu. At that time, there was already an interim government in Czechoslovakia to lead the country to its first free elections, and the communist regime was already a thing of the past, but we believe that, as part of the whole process, it is necessary to keep remembering these things, and that is why it is very good that we adopted this resolution today.

name: Vlad-Marius BOTOŞ
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, thank you very much for voting on this resolution. Thank you very much to all those who supported this resolution.  This is an important moment for my people. This is an important moment for our history, and I am very glad that we have come to give the necessary importance here, from this temple of European democracy, to the major events of 1989 that changed the way our continent has changed.  Thank you very much, and we must show the right appreciation for all the people who gave their lives in the Romanian Revolution of 1989, in order to be consistent with the message of support for the fight for human rights that the European Parliament is sending. Thank you again.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: (start of off-mic intervention) ... Uighurs calls for the same measure as the Rohingya in Burma. Natural support for human rights cannot obscure the proven infiltration of radical Islam within this Muslim minority in China, nor the question of the territorial integrity of the latter in the face of militant Islamo-nationalism. This does not detract from the intransigence that must be ours in the face of violations of fundamental freedoms, including freedom of conscience. But it is clear that China's shortcomings in this area are not new. What about, for example, the increasing restrictions on the exercise of Christian worship, since 2017, in the indifference of the international community? According to some sources, unofficial Christian churches are facing administrative closures, while others are subjected to an avalanche of vexations, such as the censorship of homilies. Let us not pretend, therefore, to discover the authoritarianism which has always been the hallmark of the Chinese regime, and against which an attitude of firmness must, on our side, finally prevail.

name: Jan ZAHRADIL
text: – Madam President, once again, I think it is very good that we have dealt with this issue here and that we have adopted a resolution on it. Here, in the European Parliament, we sometimes see a double standard when it comes to Central America and Latin America. Our colleagues on the left half of the political spectrum are very happy to criticise those regimes that are ideologically uncomfortable or uncomfortable to them, they are very happy to criticise, for example, the Brazilian President, the Chilean President, they like to criticise the situation in Colombia, but they are much more reticent when it comes to other states with regard to Venezuela or Cuba or, after all, Bolivia, where the President had to run directly from the country, or even Nicaragua. But human rights violations in these countries should also be highlighted and not double standards.

name: Patrick BREYER
text: –Madam President, the Pirate Delegation is in favour of holding the powerful accountable for grave violations of human rights, including by way of effective sanctions. However, this should be done in line with international law, and this includes the principle of Head-of-State immunity, and furthermore, sanctions should primarily be imposed by the United Nations. Now, this Parliament resolution on Nicaragua doesn’t really take these measures into account, and especially its calls for sanctions, inter alia, on the president of Nicaragua, the acting Head of State, and therefore, we decided to abstain on that specific split vote.

name: Matthew PATTEN
text: – Madam President, I voted for the resolution condemning the violent crackdown in Iran. I think I join with my MEP colleagues in absolutely deploring the deaths that have been created there and also the imprisonment of political prisoners like Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe, who should be freed immediately. But I would say this: gestures like this resolution will only go so far. There’s nothing better that my MEP colleagues really like than virtue-signalling about the US and particularly President Trump. But America is the only nation that has the power, the resource and the relationships to help us achieve what we want to achieve through this resolution. So going forwards, I would respectfully ask my colleagues to respect what has been Europe’s greatest protector and ally for many, many years, and if we want to make a difference in Tehran, we need to start in Washington.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the Commission's statement announcing the US Trade Representative: Section 301 investigation on the digital tax (2019/2979(RSP)). I would also like to remind you before this debate that you can ask for the possibility of spontaneous intervention and the use of the blue card, both in the usual way and through the electronic system. Instructions for use are available at the entrance to the Chamber.

name: Phil Hogan
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, in 2018 the Commission made two proposals to ensure that digital companies pay their fair share of taxes. These are a short-term target, a solution on digital services taxation and a long—term comprehensive solution that adjusts the definition of permanent establishment in order to include digital presence as a basis of taxing rights for corporation tax. The European Parliament supported the digital services tax proposals in its report, exactly a year ago, on 13 December 2018 and this proposal for an EU digital service tax was presented pending a comprehensive solution. It aims to address the increasing pressures that are faced by Member States to act, given the risk that their corporate tax base is being eroded significantly over time and the perceived unfairness of the situation. The proposal can also accelerate discussions at the OECD level to find a global solution on taxation issues, including a global digital service tax. Unfortunately, the Council did not find agreement on the Commission proposals at the beginning of 2019 and France and some other Member States then proceeded to adopt or prepare national digital service taxes. The United States started a so—called Section 301 investigation into the French digital service tax in July 2019. This is the first US investigation into a digital service tax, despite France being neither the first nor the only country that has adopted it. Following this, President Macron and President Trump agreed on the margins of a G7 meeting in Biarritz that France would continue levying the tax and would reimburse companies if subsequently there was a difference between the French tax and the OECD global solution. Despite this agreement, the United States continued with its investigation with a negative determination on 2 December 2019, claiming that France’s digital service tax is unreasonable, discriminatory and burdens or restricts US commerce. This determination opens the route for unilateral measures under US law. The same rules have previously been used only in response to unfair trading practices in China’s non-market economy in order to justify US tariffs against China. The only acceptable route to address trade disputes is through the World Trade Organisation adjudication process and the United States committed itself internationally and domestically to using that route in the past. The Commission therefore calls upon the US not to break its obligations under international law or under the multilateral trading system. President von der Leyen made clear that the European Union will act and react as one against any unilateral measures outside the multilateral trading system. The European Union will collectively defend a Member State if a trading partner takes unilateral trade measures against it. A fast conclusion of the update of the enforcement regulation by the Council and Parliament would send a strong signal that the European Union is ready to protect itself and the multilateral trading system. So let me conclude by saying that it would be a matter of significant concern to the Commission if the United States should decide to introduce tariffs against the European Union, based on a unilateral determination of Section 301B of the Trade Agreements Act of 1974. It would be the first time that the United States has used this instrument against the European Union since the World Trade Organisation was founded in 1995 and the United States statute envisages further discussions as an option instead of trade restrictive measures. So we in the Commission will keep on pushing for these discussions.

name: Marie-Pierre VEDRENNE
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. Mr President, Commissioner, we are here for the last plenary debate of 2019. This debate reflects the situation we have been facing for several years in international trade. International trade, as we all know, is going through a period of severe turbulence. The world has changed, with China's place, that of digital, but have the rules of international trade been able to adapt? I don't think so. However, I will always advocate, as will you, balanced and rules-based international trade. Today, we Europeans are under pressure and Donald Trump is targeting us once again. Let us remember, the latter first chose to tax European steel and aluminium, for almost two years now, illegally. The European Union has retaliated, but how effectively? Since mid-October, our European producers and farmers have been subject to additional tariffs of 25% imposed by the United States in the Airbus/Boeing case. Again, Donald Trump has decided to strike hard, with 6.8 billion euros in sanctions. As you pointed out, on December 2, and that is the purpose of our exchange, the Trump administration announced its intention to overtax up up to 100%, for the equivalent of $2.4 billion, of French products, in response to the introduction of a tax on digital services. This announcement is extremely worrying. At the initiative of the Renew Group and the Renaissance delegation, this debate could be added to the agenda of this session, before the January deadline set by the Americans. It is important to take stock of the issues and I know, Commissioner, that you share this concern. What does Donald Trump blame us for? He believes that the tax on digital services would be discriminatory. I agree: this tax represents a fair contribution to pay for digital companies. The European Union seeks to foster the emergence of an international solution within the framework of the OECD. Discussions must continue in order to achieve fair taxation of digital enterprises, guaranteeing fair competition. In this offensive against the tax on digital services, Donald Trump has targeted the jewels of the French economy: champagne, roquefort, butter, cosmetics, handbags. It strikes where the damage is done, because the United States, which is just one example, remains the largest market in value for French champagne. Even more worrying: while a few large French and European groups will be affected, it is above all our SMEs, TPEs and farmers who will be the hardest hit. These new taxes could be fatal to them. Farmers and producers are once again paying the high price of trade and political tensions. In the event of sanctions, support measures will have to be taken. I would like to emphasize several points today. First of all, the need for dialogue: between two major partners, dialogue must take precedence and we must put an end to this tug-of-war. The European Union has always been open to discussion and we hope that the United States will hear us. This escalation in trade tensions will ultimately only be a loser. A win-win solution must be found, because it will be the producers, but also the consumers on both sides of the Atlantic, who will suffer the negative effects of the lack of a solution. Another point is the need for unity: preserving solidarity between Member States is part of our values. It is in unity that the European Union was created; It's our DNA. And I thank you, Commissioner Hogan, for saying, once again today, that unity is our strength. Finally, this debate is a reminder of the urgency we face, the need to strengthen our trade policy. It is our economy that suffers from our lack of responsiveness. The European Union is the world's leading trading power; it is time to assert it more and be more offensive. To conclude and to return to this new announcement from the United States, the message I am sending today is clear: the escalation that continues is not a viable or reasonable solution; it must be put to an end.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Commissioner Hogan, honourable colleague Marie-Pierre Vedren, honourable two other colleagues, it is an honour to be part of such an epic and tense debate, such a fierce debate in this Chamber. We show the attitude of European representatives to such topics. We've had four representatives in the chamber since 751. True, holidays lie ahead, but still this is quite indicative. That is why I congratulate you, Mr President, for being very strict over time and following the rules. If it's said, there could be a heated debate between the four of us, we can argue. I don't know if you're famous, but it's played by four people. We have plenty of time to make such a theme.  It is indicative that the people in the gallery who look at us are a dozen times more than us, and these people are most affected by the debated issue, because the tax on digital services will affect every single app they use, every phone they use and every single service they use. But you see what the attitude of colleagues is. That's very telling, we're giving a policy lesson, we're teaching them politics right now.  But let's get to the heart of it. On July 10, 2019, the Office of the U.S. Trade Representative launched an investigation into the digital services tax proposed by the Government of France. This French law would impose a 3% tax on the total annual revenue generated by some companies from providing certain digital services on the French market. According to the draft law, the tax applies only to companies with total revenues from service coverage of at least EUR 750 million worldwide and EUR 25 million in France.  The scope of these services is quite naturally in the sphere where American companies are world leaders. The structure of the proposed new tax, as well as statements by some officials in France, show that it is disproportionately targeted at these American companies. It is clear to me that the balance between fair taxation and maintaining good relations with our closest allies is very delicate.  Reciprocal actions on the American side are not in our interest. We all know and remember what happened when the U.S. administration launched a trade war with China. The problems there have not been solved and are yet to deepen. I don't think the European Union should be in that position, especially when it comes to trade with one of our closest allies.  My group in the European Parliament will continue to defend the right to free trade and free market. This is how we can provide prosperity for our citizens. Therefore, work must be made to resolve this issue. France does not represent the whole of Europe. I hope her example will not be followed by other countries.  I want to draw the attention of this powerful group of four people and something else. In this chamber, we often hear calls for the unification of the tax burden in different countries of the European Union. Usually they come from the leftist Communists in the European Parliament. I would like to point out that we are firmly opposed to such harmful proposals. The tax policy of a state is its sovereign right.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Mr Dzhambazki, I would like to correct you in one: there are not four, but five. You have forgotten me, and you must always count on me.

name: Maria WALSH
text: – Mr President, I’m going to carry suit from my ECR colleague and say it is disappointing that – at the time this is being held – we don’t have more MEPs sitting in the Hemicycle. Commissioner Hogan, directly to you: I applaud you and your teams’ work to date, even though it’s just been a few short weeks since you’ve taken up your role as Commissioner. As a representative of Ireland, in particular as a representative of Midlands-North West, I urge you to continue on your message of EU solidarity, particularly under the guidance of tax – and you’re looking at digitalisation or product or what not – when in conversation with the United States of America at this turbulent time. And with that I say any support, from an Irish front, we can give, we are here to do so.

name: Phil Hogan
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I want to thank the speakers for their engagement on this issue to assure the speakers as well that we will continue our efforts to engage with the United States in relation to all trade matters, including the issues before the House this evening on the digital tax and to assure you that in January I will be visiting the United States, and make every effort to work on a solution to this very important matter. And can I take the opportunity, Mr President, to thank you and your team for your kindness and cooperation with the Commission in 2019 and to wish you and all of your team for 2019 and indeed 2020 the compliments of the season.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Ladies and gentlemen! We have reached the end of the 2019 session.  We all know the business, what it looks like on Thursday afternoons. Visitors don't know the business. The last session – some of them have already left, had to leave. I would be very attached to the new year if I could express a wish that the speakers who speak on Thursday afternoon would not just deplore it. Because remember, your speeches will be recorded, your speeches can be called up, and if at some point you will use a speech on this subject, you do not know whether it was on a Thursday or on a Tuesday afternoon, and then the people outside think much worse. Then they think that this is the case every day, and that is not the case, the plenary was full at noon today. I would also like to wish you all a quiet time between the years. A blessed Christmas and a good start in the new year. I wish you all, as I say every year, every success, and much success, at least to the extent that it does not harm my political homeland. I am happy to continue to work together properly and hope to see you again, not in old, but in new freshness. I would like to thank not only the Members, the Commission, but also all the services on the left and right and behind me and behind the glass panes – our interpreters, who are, so to speak, our parliamentary air to breathe. Without these interpreters, most of us would not be understood, and even less so, because I have a heavy accent, for which I also apologise to the interpreters. I am also looking forward to working with them next year. Out of line: Mr Dzhambazki, you said that I was always very strict. That's right. Normally, you wouldn't get the word on the blue card now. But I want to give it to you.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: – You have just refuted me, for which I thank you. I congratulate you, you've always been strict in following time, and so it should be. With regard to your note on when meetings are held, it may be necessary to consider whether there should be thursday meetings so that the chamber is not so empty. This is a matter of organisation that we need to do as members of parliament. Now allow me to join your congratulations and thanks to you, and the Commissioner and his team, your associates, the translators, and wish them happy Christmas holidays and next year with new powers back here.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The debate is closed.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: I declare the session of the European Parliament adjourned.
